column1: 2017AGUFM.P44B..01S|2017|Strong Evidence of Variable Micro-meteor Flux from Apollo 17 Samples Obtained at Shorty Crater and on the Light Mantle Avalanche at Taurus-Littrow|Schmitt
column4: N. E.|AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts|2017||P44B-01|Light-gray regolith overlying the orange and black pyroclastic ash (Schmitt
column5: 2017) at Shorty Crater protected the ash from incorporation into surrounding basaltic regolith for 3.5 billion years (Tera and Wasserburg
column7: 1979). Inspection of LROC images indicate this regolith probably came from a 350 m diameter
column9: about 1 km NNE of Shorty. This regolith was derived largely from basalt and spread over the ash deposit about 24 Myr (Eugster
column12: corrected for post-Shorty exposure) after the last ash eruption. Maturity indexes for light gray regolith samples 74441 and 74461 are about 8 (Morris
column13: 1978) and agglutinate concentrations are 8% and 7.7% (Heiken and McKay
column15: respectively. These values are inconsistent with the exposure and cycling of the light-gray regolith during 3.5 billion years in the lunar surface impact environment (i.e.
column16: the time between ash deposition and the light mantle avalanche). If agglutinate content and Is/FeO indexes largely reflect the cumulative effect of micro-meteor impacts
column18: the light-gray regolith formed in an environment with significantly less micro-meteor flux than that which has prevailed more recently. 14-18% of fragile
column19: ropy glass in the light-gray regolith
column20: as compared with <1% in presently exposed Taurus-Littrow regoliths
column21: also is consistent with low micro-meteor flux during development. The high recent micro-meteor flux appears to have existed for at least for the last 75 million years (Schmitt
column24: the estimated time using LROC-based crater frequency analysis (van der Bogert
column26: 2012) since the light mantle avalanche of South Massif regolith covered the light-gray regolith. New regolith on the light mantle appears to be developing a higher concentration of agglutinates and a higher maturity index relative to regolith in deeper portions of the unit. Light mantle avalanche samples 73141 (subsurface) and 73121 (near surface)
column27: have agglutinates at 32% and 42% and Is/FeO indexes of 48 and 78
column28: respectively. This difference further supports the hypothesis of a highly variable micro-meteor flux throughout lunar history
column29: with its current flux being significantly higher than for some period both prior to and subsequent to 3.5 Ga.|

column9: R.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||339|Electron microprobe analyses have been performed on glasses of impact origin in Apollo 11 breccias (10059
column16: 15427). These glasses were produced by shock melting of regolith
column17: rather than of rock. Simple concepts for better understanding and interpreting the chemical data from impact glasses have been developed. These concepts are a significant improvement on earlier strategies
column18: which centered principally on cluster analysis. Using ratios of refractory lithophile elements
column19: the compositional effects of fractional vaporization often associated with impact melting to obtain chemical information about the mare and highland components in the regoliths parental to the glasses have been 'seen through'. This method is also applied to the mare-derived impact glasses from Apollo 16 in order to place constraints on the types of volcanic components occurring in Mare Nectaris. Since impact glasses can be used to derive chemical constraints on the indigenous lithologies comprising multi-component regoliths; the frequent occurrence of these glasses
column20: as well as their low masses
column21: should make them critically important for study when small quantities of grab-samples are returned by future unmanned spacecraft from planets
column23: and asteroids where regoliths are present.|

column1: 1981LPI....12..918R|1981|The Apollo 17 Highlands: the South Massif Soils|Ryder
1978LPSC....9.2287M|1978|The surface exposure (maturity) of lunar soils: Some concepts and I<SUB>S</SUB>/FeO compilation.|Morris
column2: R. V.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||2287|Surface exposure (or
column4: maturity) indices of lunar soils are a measure of residence time of soil in the upper one millimeter of the regolith. Several concepts concerning the use of and terminology associated with maturity indices are discussed. For reasons which include its generally-applicable nature and large data base
column5: the ferromagnetic resonance (FMR) surface exposure (maturity) index I<SUB>s/FeO</SUB> (the ratio of the value of the intensity in arbitrary units of the FMR resonance at g equal to about 2.1 to the FeO concentration) is particularly suitable and useful. A compilation of values of I<SUB>s/FeO</SUB> for 164 Apollo surface and trench soils and six Luna 24 core soils is given.|
